{{Infobox video game | title = The Park | image = File:ThePark KeyArt.jpg | caption = | developer = [[Funcom]] | publisher = Funcom | director = Joel Bylos | artist = Gavin Whelan | series = ''[[The Secret World]]'' | engine = [[Unreal Engine 4]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]
[[PlayStation 4]]
[[Xbox One]] | released = {{Unbulleted list|'''Microsoft Windows'''|October 27, 2015|'''PlayStation 4''', '''Xbox One'''|May 3, 2016}} | genre = [[Adventure game#Exploration games|Exploration]] | modes = [[Single-player]] }} '''''The Park''''' is a [[first-person (video games)|first-person]] [[psychological horror]] [[adventure game]] developed and published by [[Funcom]].{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=Christopher|title=The Park is a short, experimental horror game from Funcom coming this Oct.|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/8/26/9210089/the-park-horror-game-funcom|publisher=Polygon|accessdate=6 November 2015}} The game was released via [[Steam (software)|Steam]] on October 27, 2015 and is a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of an earlier Funcom game, ''[[The Secret World]]''.{{cite web|last1=Conditt|first1=Jessica|title='The Park' isn't your typical haunted-carnival horror game|url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/10/21/the-park-horror-game-funcom-parenting/|publisher=Engadget|accessdate=6 November 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Adam|title=Wot I Think: The Park|url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/10/28/the-park-review/|publisher=Rock Paper Shotgun|accessdate=6 November 2015}} It was released for [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] on May 3, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-18-funcoms-horror-game-the-park-dated-for-ps4-and-xbox-one|title=Funcom's horror game The Park was released on PS4 and Xbox One in May|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=April 18, 2016|accessdate=April 19, 2016}} ==Gameplay== {{expand section|date=March 2016}} ''The Park'' is experienced from a first-person perspective as the player interacts with and experiences the decrepit environment of Atlantic Island Park. There is no combat or defense and the player has no health HUD as Lorraine can only interact with limited objects in-game and there are no enemies to battle. These objects mostly consist of pages that reveal the backstory of the park and later, Lorraine. Lorraine can call out to Callum at any time during gameplay, and this may have a small affect as it allows Lorraine to follow Callum's voice and thus continue the narrative of the story or to reach necessary areas or objectives within the park such as the rides. The rides act as both exposition and scares. To enter the House of Horrors, Lorraine must find a flashlight. Throughout the game, Lorraine narrates her feelings and memories to the player. ==Plot== {{more plot|date=March 2016}} The game follows Lorraine, a struggling [[Single parents#Mother|single mother]] and [[widow]] with a troubled past, as she searches for her young son, Callum, who goes missing in Atlantic Island Park. Lorraine enters the park after her son just as the park prepares to close for the afternoon, only to find that nighttime comes unnaturally fast as she ascends the escalator and discovers the park to be abandoned, vandalized and rundown as if several years have passed. Despite abandonment, the rides and lights mysteriously still function. Lorraine calls for Callum and his voice calls to her, leading her through the decrepit park. Lorraine boards several rides which reveal the themes and backstory of the game: the Tunnel of Tales tells the story of [[Hansel and Gretel]], this time with a new ending - in which after cooking the witch in the oven, Hansel and Gretel devour her. On the [[Ferris Wheel]], Lorraine remembers Callum's father Don, a [[construction worker]] at the park who died in a fall from the Ferris Wheel when Lorraine was still pregnant with Callum. Between rides, Lorraine expresses her frustration with Callum, her belief that she is a failure as a mother, her history of mental health problems, and her fear that Callum is becoming changed by some mysterious threat. However, while aboard the roller coaster, a monstrous top-hatted [[Ringmaster (circus)|ringmaster]] (identified in the credits as The [[Boogeyman]]) accosts Lorraine and claims 'the Witch' has her son. According to notes found throughout the area, the park's grounds are hinted to have a sinister history that [[Energy (esotericism)|tainted]] them, as a consequence of previous owner Archibald Henderson's actions, which the new owner Mr. Winter tried to take advantage of: several notes indicate that he had found a way to unlock the power hidden beneath the grounds by harvesting the positive emotions of guests, and believed that the energy he unlocked would be enough to grant him [[immortality]]. However, workers and employees alike experienced feelings of anxiety as a result of the process, and a number of fatal incidents occurred. One noticeable case involved 'Chad the Chipmunk', the park's mascot: Steve, the employee wearing the chipmunk suit, became disturbed and reluctant to remove the suit as time went on - and ultimately murdered a teenager with an icepick. Following Steve's arrest and the disappearance of over a dozen children inside the House of Horrors, the Park was forced to close permanently, drawing Lorraine's perceptions during the introduction into question. At last, Lorraine enters the witch-faced House of Horrors, still following Callum, and remarking on the similarity between this and the Hansel and Gretel story. Inside, messages from Mr. Winter reveal that he retreated into the House with his machines when the Park closed, hoping to achieve immortality by other means. However, the interior of the House changes to a loop of Lorraine and Callum's own home through time, where it is revealed that Lorraine's father abused and abducted her as a child, her estranged mother refuses to help her in the belief that she ran away from home, and she suffered from [[Depression (mood)|depression]] when Callum was born and given [[electroshock therapy]]. As Lorraine passes through each version of her house, it becomes more decrepit and disturbing. At the end, she finds a message by Mr. Winter revealing that he needs children for his harvesting machines, and has already kidnapped and killed at least one in order to fuel his immortality; notes such as these, combined with popular depictions of Winter in a similar ringmaster's garb and top hat, suggest that he is actually the Boogeyman haunting the grounds. Lorraine reveals that in the oldest versions of the Hansel and Gretel story, the cruel mother and the Witch were the same person, and that she believes she is the real Witch - apparently accepting that her neglect of Callum was the indirect cause of Callum's disappearance. Finally, she reaches Callum, lying unconscious on a slab. Chad the Chipmunk appears behind her, then is replaced by the Boogeyman, who forces a bloody icepick into Lorraine's hands, then guides her hands so she holds the point above Callum's chest; however, he then releases her hands and vanishes, allowing Lorraine to stab Callum in the heart. Afterwards, Lorraine is sitting in a police station interrogation room, clearly grief-stricken. A detective identical to the Park gatekeeper enters, carrying a jar with a bee in it, and tells her not to worry about losing things and to think of the last place she saw her son. Lorraine narrates that, in her heart and mind, she will always return to Atlantic Island Park. Ultimately, though the supernatural elements of the game are eventually confirmed to be true by the game's ties with ''The Secret World'' and Lorraine's appearance in later issues of the game, it's left ambiguous as to how much of ''The Park'' was real and how much was simply imaginary. ==Development== ''The Park'' was announced by Funcom on August 26, 2015. According to Funcom's Rui Casais, the games' development began as an experiment by a small team. The team hoped to utilize the worlds from their previous [[massively multiplayer online]] games, and reshape them into some smaller single-player games. According to Casasis, it was "creatively energising" for the team to work on a new single-player game as their last game with a single-player focus was ''[[Dreamfall: The Longest Journey]]'' in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/08/26/funcom-announces-new-horror-game-the-park|title=Funcom Announces New Horror Game The Park|first=Vikki|last=Blake|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 25, 2016|accessdate=April 19, 2016}} The game's universe is based on 2012's ''[[The Secret World]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/the-park-is-a-short-horror-game-set-in-the-secret-worlds-universe/|title=The Park is a short horror game set in The Secret World's universe|first=James|last=Davenport|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=August 26, 2016|accessdate=April 19, 2016}} The game was announced for [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Xbox One]] in November 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2015/11/17/psychological-horror-game-the-park-coming-to-consoles.aspx|title=Psychological Horror Game The Park Coming To Consoles|first=Joseph|last=Knoop|date=November 15, 2016|accessdate=April 19, 2016|work=[[Game Informer]]}} Funcom later announced that the console versions will be released on May 3, 2016, making it the first Funcom game developed for consoles since ''Dreamfall'' in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-18-funcoms-horror-game-the-park-dated-for-ps4-and-xbox-one|title=Funcom's horror game The Park is coming to PS4 and Xbox One in May|first=Jeffery|last=Matulef|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=April 18, 2016|accessdate=April 19, 2016}} ==Reception== The game currently holds a rating of 67 out of 100 on [[Metacritic]] based on 25 reviews, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|title=The Park|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/the-park/critic-reviews|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=16 August 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.theparkgame.com/}} {{Funcom}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Park, The (2015 game)}} [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Exploration video games]] [[Category:Funcom games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Psychological horror games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Norway]] [[Category:Video games featuring female protagonists]] [[Category:Video games set in amusement parks]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox One games]]

revision.text:
{{about|the wilds|the wild|wilderness|other uses|Bush (disambiguation)}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[Image:Australian bush.jpg|thumb|right|The Australian bush]]
"'''The bush'''" is a rural, undeveloped country area in certain areas.
==Usage by country== ===Australia=== [[File:Australian bush02.jpg|thumb|Australian bush in the state of [[Victoria (state)|Victoria]].]] The concept of "the bush" has become iconic in Australia.<ref> {{cite web |url = http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/austn-bush |title = The Australian Bush |author = Australian Government, Culture Portal |date = 11 December 2007 |accessdate = 5 December 2009 |quote = The bush has an iconic status in Australian life and features strongly in any debate about national identity |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120227101247/http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/austn-bush |archivedate = 27 February 2012 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> In reference to the landscape, "bush" refers to any sparsely-inhabited region, regardless of vegetation. "The bush" in this sense was something that was uniquely Australian{{cn|date=November 2015}} and very different from the green European landscapes familiar to many new immigrants. The term "[[Outback]]" is also used, but usually in association with the more arid inland areas of Australia. "The Bush" also refers to any populated region outside of the major metropolitan areas, including mining and [[agriculture in Australia|agricultural areas]]. Consequently, it is not unusual to have a mining town in the desert such as [[Port Hedland]] (Pop. 14,000) referred to as "the bush" within the media.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-08-28/grocerychoice-useless-for-those-in-the-bush-tuckey/492284 |title= GroceryChoice useless for those in the bush: Tuckey |date= 28 August 2008 |publisher= [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref>
[[Bush ballad|Bush poets]] such as [[Henry Lawson]] and [[Banjo Paterson]] revered the bush as a source of national ideals, as did contemporaneous painters in the [[Heidelberg School]] like [[Tom Roberts]] (1856-1931), [[Arthur Streeton]] (1867-1943) and [[Frederick McCubbin]] (1855-1917).<ref name="aupa">{{Cite news |url= http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/austn-painters |title= Australian painters |accessdate= 5 November 2012 |date= 23 November 2007 |publisher= Commonwealth of Australia |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121021091855/http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/austn-painters |archivedate= 21 October 2012 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Romanticising the bush in this way was a big step forward for Australians in their steps towards [[self-identity]].{{cn|date=November 2015}} The legacy is a [[folklore]] rich in the spirit of the bush.
Australians affix the term "bush" to any number of other entities or activities to describe their rural, country or folk nature, e.g. "[[Cricket|Bush Cricket]]", "[[Australian folk music|Bush Music]]", "[[Doof|Bush Doof]]", etc.
===New Zealand=== {{see also|Forest parks of New Zealand|Deforestation in New Zealand}} <!-- This section is linked from [[Auckland]] --> [[Image:LakeGunnBush.jpg|thumb|right|New Zealand's bush is variable in appearance, but generally the term connotates densely forested areas, like this one around [[Lake Gunn]] in [[Fiordland]].]]
In New Zealand, ''Bush'' primarily refers to areas of native trees rather than exotic forests, however, the word is also used in the Australian sense of anywhere outside urban areas, encompassing grasslands as well as forests.<ref name=" Jock Phillips">{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/the-New-Zealand-bush/1 |title=The New Zealand bush – What is the bush? (The bush: dense native forest) |author=Jock Phillips |date=17 September 2009 |publisher=[[Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]]}}</ref>
The New Zealand usage of "bush" probably comes from the word "bosch", used by Dutch settlers in South Africa, where it meant uncultivated country.<ref name="Jock Phillips"/>
Areas with bush (i.e. native forest) are found predominantly in the [[South Island]], especially in the [[West Coast, New Zealand|West Coast]] region stretching from [[Fiordland]] to [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]], with the east coast having been deforested except for parts of [[Kaikoura]] and [[the Catlins]]. Much of [[Stewart Island/Rakiura]] is bush-covered. In the [[North Island]], the largest areas of bush cover the main ranges stretching north-northeast from [[Wellington]] towards [[East Cape]], notably including the [[Te Urewera|Urewera Ranges]], and the catchment of the [[Whanganui River]]. Significant stands remain in Northland and the ranges running south from the Coromandel Peninsula towards Ruapehu, and isolated remnants cap various volcanoes in Taranaki, the Waikato, the Bay of Plenty and the Hauraki Gulf.
From the word comes many phrases including:<ref>{{cite book |last=Orsman |first=H. W. |title=The Dictionary of New Zealand English |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=1999 |location=Auckland |isbn=0-19-558347-7}}</ref> * bush-bash – to make one's way through the forest, rather than on a track or trail (''cf.'' American English "bushwhack[ing]", "bushwack[ing]", or "bush-whack[ing]"). * bush shirt – a woolen shirt or [[Swanndri]], often worn by forest workers. * [[bush lawyer (plant)|bush lawyer]] – the name of a number of native climbing plants or a layman who expounds on legal matters. * bush walk – short day walks ([[hiking|hikes]]) in the bush * going bush – to live in the bush for an extended period of time, which may include "living off the land" by means of hunting or fishing. * Bushman - Used in the 19th century for New Zealand loggers. The term still stands for someone that lives in the bush as a means of preferable lifestyle.
===South Africa=== In South Africa, the term has specific connotations of rural areas which are not open [[veldt]]. Generally, it refers to areas in the north of the country that would be called [[savanna]]. "Going to The Bush" often refers to going to a game park or game reserve. Areas most commonly referred to as The Bush are the [[Mpumalanga]] and [[Limpopo]] [[Lowveld]], The [[Limpopo River]] Valley, northern [[KwaZulu-Natal]] or any other similar area of wilderness.
===Alaska and Canada=== {{Main|The Bush (Alaska)}} The Bush in Alaska is generally described as any community not "on the road system", making it accessible only by more elaborate transportation. Usage is similar in Canada; it is called ''la brousse,'' if you are French or colloquially ''Le Bois,'' in [[Canadian French]]. In northern Ontario, “the bush” refers to the massive expanse of primarily coniferous trees that sprawl undeveloped towards the northern eastern and western borders of the province. The term is not generally used in the southern parts of the province.
==Related terms== [[File:Bush icons.JPG|thumb|right|Icons of the Australian bush: [[bracken]], [[corrugated iron]], [[banksia]], felt hat, [[billycan|billy]], [[stockwhip]] and elastic-side boots.]]
The term "to go bush" has several similar meanings all connected with the supposed wildness of the bush. It can mean to revert to a feral nature (or to "go native"), and it can also mean to deliberately leave normal surroundings and live rough, with connotations of cutting off communication with the outside world – often as a means of evading capture or questioning by the police. The term ''bushwhacker'' is used in Australia and New Zealand to mean someone who spends his or her time in the bush.
Another related term used in Australia is "Sydney or the bush", which equates with such terms as "Hollywood or bust" to mean staking total success or failure on one high-risk event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com.au/details.php?e=161|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030907120654/http://www.artnews.com.au/details.php?e=161|dead-url=yes|archive-date=7 September 2003|title=Sydney or the bush|date=29 November 2002|author=John McDonald}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/ra/australia/pdf/sydney_bush.pdf |title=CONTEMPORARY AUSTRALIA 5. Sydney or the Bush? |author=Chris Baker |date=6 June 2006 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |format=[[PDF]]}}</ref> This usage appears in several ''[[Peanuts]]'' cartoons, causing Charlie Brown much confusion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/peanuts/2012/08/29/|title=Peanuts|date=29 August 2012|author=[[Charles M. Schulz]]}}</ref>
In addition, many [[Vietnam War]] Veterans refer to the wilderness, jungle or border areas of the theatre of operations as "the bush", as opposed to towns, cities and military bases.
In New Zealand, "The Bush" is a nickname for the [[Wairarapa Bush Rugby Football Union|Wairarapa Bush provincial rugby team]]. The team was formed by an amalgamation of two earlier teams ([[Wairarapa]] and Bush), the latter of which represented an area on the boundaries of the Wairarapa and [[Hawke's Bay]] which was in former times known as Bush, due to its dense vegetation cover.
[[The Bushwhackers]] were also a New Zealand professional wrestling tag team that was inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] class of 2015.
To ''bushwhack'' has two meanings, one is to cut through heavy brush and other vegetation to pass through the tangled country: "We had to do quite a bit of bushwhacking today to clear the new trail." The other meaning is to hide in such areas and then attack unsuspecting passers-by: "We were bushwhacked by the bandits as we passed through their territory and they took all of our money and supplies."
In the United States, the term has a similar meaning, for example in [[minor league baseball]], typically played in smaller cities, and sometimes derisively called "bush league" baseball.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Bushcraft]] *[[Bush flying]] *[[Bush tucker]] *[[Bushland]] *[[Bushranger]] *[[Bush mechanic]] *[[Old-growth forest]] *[[Outback]] *[[Wilderness]] *[[Black stump]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bush}} [[Category:Geography of Alaska]] [[Category:Geography of Australia]] [[Category:Geography of New Zealand]] [[Category:Geography of South Africa]] [[Category:Geography of Canada]] [[Category:Rural geography]]

revision.text:
{{main article|Matterhorn}} {{TOC right}}
==Timeline== [[File:Matterhorn ascent Dore.jpg|thumb|[[First ascent of the Matterhorn]], [[engraving]] by [[Gustave Dore]]]]
===1857=== * July: First attempt (from [[Breuil-Cervinia|Breuil]]) by [[Jean-Antoine Carrel]], Jean-Jacques Carrel, and [[Amé Gorret]].<ref name = Staelen>[http://www.acorfi.asso.fr/passe/2000-01/20001121.html Pierre Staelen: La Conquête du Cervin] Retrieved 2010-01-18</ref>
===1858=== * August: Attempt by J. A. and J. J. Carrel. The ''Grande Tour'' is reached (3800 m).<ref name = Staelen/>
===1860=== * July 2: Attempt from Zermatt (East face) by Charles, Alfred and Sandbach Parker (c. 3500 m)<ref name = Scrambles>Edward Whymper, ''Scrambles amongst the Alps'' (table of attempts and ascents)</ref> * August: Attempt by [[John Tyndall]], Vaughan Hawkins, J. J. Carrel (3960 m)<ref name = Staelen/>
===1861=== * July 4: Second attempt by the Parker brothers (c. 3570 m)<ref name = Scrambles/> * August 29: J. A. and J. J. Carrel. The ''Crête du Coq'' is reached (4032 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * August 29–30: First attempt by [[Edward Whymper]] and Swiss guide (Lion ridge)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/>
===1862=== * January: First winter attempt (from Zermatt East face) by Thomas Stuart Kennedy guided by Peter Perren and [[Peter Taugwalder]] (c. 3350 m)<ref name = Scrambles/><ref>D.F.O. Dangar & T.S. Blakeney, [http://www.alpinejournal.org.uk/Contents/Contents_1965_files/AJ%201965%207-47%20Matterhorn.pdf 'Old' Peter Taugwalder, 1820-88], [[The Alpine Journal]] Vol. 50, pp. 26-29</ref> * July 7–8: Attempt by E. Whymper, Reginald J. S. MacDonald, Johann zum Taugwald, Johann Krönig, Luc Meynet (3657 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * July 9–10: Attempt by E. Whymper, R. J. S. MacDonald, J. A. Carrel, Pession (3960 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * July 18–19: Solo attempt by E. Whymper (4084 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * July 23–24: Attempt by E. Whymper, J. A. Carrel, César Carrel, L. Meynet (4008 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * July 25–26: Attempt by E. Whymper, L. Meynet (4102 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * July 27–28: Attempt by J. Tyndall, {{Interlanguage link multi|Johann Joseph Bennen|de}}, Anton Walters, J. A. Carrel, C. Carrel. The ''Shoulder'' is reached ([[Pic Tyndall]], 4258 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/>
===1863=== * August 10–11: Attempt by E. Whymper, J. A. Carrel, C. Carrel, L. Meynet and two porters (4047 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/>
===1865=== * June 21: Attempt from the south east face (Furggen couloir) by E. Whymper, [[Michel Croz]], [[Christian Almer]], Franz Biner, L. Meynet (3414 m)<ref name = Staelen/><ref name = Scrambles/> * July: Attempt by J. A. Carrel, C. Carrel, Charles Gorret, {{Interlanguage link multi|Jean-Joseph Maquignaz|fr}}. Pic Tyndall, 4258 m<ref name = Staelen/> * '''July 14: [[First ascent of the Matterhorn|First ascent]]''' (Hörnli ridge) by E. Whymper, [[Lord Francis Douglas|Francis Douglas]], [[Charles Hudson (climber)|Charles Hudson]], [[Douglas Hadow]], M. Croz, P. Taugwalder (father), Peter Taugwalder (son). Death of Douglas, Hudson, Hadow and Croz on the descent.<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name = SAC>''Guide des Alpes Valaisannes, du Col Collon au Theodulpass'', 1992, [[Swiss Alpine Club]]</ref> * '''July 17: 2nd ascent''': [[Second ascent of the Matterhorn|First ascent from the Italian side]] by J.-A. Carrel and Jean-Baptiste Bich. A. Gorret, of the 1857 attempt, and Jean-Augustin Meynet stop just short of the summit.<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name=centenary>[http://www.alpinejournal.org.uk/Contents/Contents_1965_files/AJ%201965%207-47%20Matterhorn.pdf The Matterhorn Centenary], [[The Alpine Journal]] Vol. 50, pp. 9-14</ref>
===1867=== * August 15: 3rd ascent. Second ascent from Breuil by J. A. Carrel, J. B. Bich, and Salomon Meynet guiding [[Florence Crauford Grove]].<ref name = Scrambles/> * September 13: 4th ascent: First direct ascent of the Lion ridge as it is climbed today by Jean-Joseph and Jean-Pierre Maquignaz.<ref name = Scrambles/> * October 1–3: 5th ascent: From Breuil. J. J. and J. P. Maquignaz, C. Carrel and François Ansermin guiding William Leighton Jordan.<ref name=List>Whymper, Edward, [https://books.google.com/books?id=k6uScEubYogC&lpg=PA425&dq=%22james%20eccles%22%20ALPS&pg=PA425#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Scrambles amongst the Alps''], Courier Dover Publications, 1996, p. 425</ref>
===1868=== * July 25: 6th ascent: Second ascent via the Hörnli ridge by {{Interlanguage link multi|Josef Marie Lochmatter|de}} and {{Interlanguage link multi|Peter Knubel|fr}} guiding Julius Elliot.<ref name = Scrambles/> * July 28: 7th ascent: First traverse of the summit (Lion and Hörnli ridges) by J. Tyndall, J. J. and J. P. Maquignaz.<ref name = Scrambles/> * August 4: 8th ascent Second traverse of the summit (Hörnli and Lion ridges) by J. J. Maquignaz, Victor Maquignaz and Elie Pession guiding François Thioly and O. Hoiler.<ref name = Scrambles/> * August 3–4: 9th ascent: P. Knubel, Hans Baumann, Peter Bernett guiding George Edward Foster.<ref name=List/> * August 8: 10th ascent: J. M. Lochmatter, P. Knubel and Niklaus Knubel guiding [[Paul Güssfeldt]].<ref name=List/>
===1869=== * July 20: 15th ascent: J. A. Carrel, J. B. Bich, Alphonse Payot and {{Interlanguage link multi|Michel Payot|fr|Michel-Clément Payot}} guiding [[James Eccles]].<ref name=List/> * August 26: 16th ascent: Ascent of the Lion ridge by Joseph, Pierre and Emmanuel Maquignaz and <!--J.?-->B. Bich guiding [[Robert Boothby Heathcote]]; it was on this occasion that the guides fixed at the last bit the rope ladder which was called the Echelle Jordan, from the name of its donor.<ref name = Scrambles/>
===1871=== * July 22: First ascent by a woman: [[Lucy Walker (climber)|Lucy Walker]] reached the summit with her father Frank Walker and Frederick Gardiner, guided by Heinrich and [[Melchior Anderegg]], N. Knubel, P. Knubel and P. Perren.<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name=centenary/> * September 5: First traverse by a woman: [[Meta Brevoort]] with [[W.A.B. Coolidge]] guided by Chr. Almer, {{Interlanguage link multi|Ulrich Almer|fr}} and N. Knubel.<ref name=centenary/>
===1872=== * July 26: Traverse Breuil-summit-Zermatt in 18 hours by J. J. Maquignaz and Anton Ritz guiding J. Jackson.<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name = Rey>Guido Rey, ''The Matterhorn''</ref>
===1876=== * July 23: First ascent without mountain guides by John Brise Colgrove, Albert Harold Cawood and Arthur Cust.<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name = Rey/>
===1879=== * September 3: First ascent via the Zmutt ridge by [[Albert F. Mummery]], [[Alexander Burgener]], Johann Petrus and Augustin Gentinetta.<ref name = Scrambles/> ** One hour later [[William Penhall]], {{Interlanguage link multi|Ferdinand Imseng|fr}} and Louis Zurbrücken finished the first ascent (partially) over the west face (significantly overlapping the Zmutt Ridge route)<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name = SAC/> * September 6: Second ascent of the Zmutt ridge by Baumann with guides J. Petrus and [[Émile Rey]].<ref name = Scrambles/><ref name = Rey/>
===1880=== * July 16: A. Burgener, [[Benedikt Venetz]] and A. F. Mummery attempted the first ascent of the Furggen ridge. At the level of the Swiss Shoulder they were forced to traverse along the east face to the Swiss ridge, to climb to the summit by the ordinary route.<ref name=centenary/><ref name = Rey/>
===1881=== * August 4: Ascent by future US President [[Theodore Roosevelt]], guided by Taugwalder. <ref>[http://www.theodorerooseveltcenter.org/Research/Digital-Library/Record/ImageViewer?libID=o288503&imageNo=46 Theodor Roosevelt Personal Diary, 1881]</ref><ref>[http://www.theodorerooseveltcenter.org/Research/Digital-Library/Record/ImageViewer?libID=o278913&imageNo=1 Theodore Roosevelt - letter to his sister]</ref>
===1882=== * March 16: First winter ascent (Lion ridge) by J. A. Carrel, J. Baptiste Carrel and Louis Carrel guiding [[Vittorio Sella]]. Descent via the Hörnli ridge (17th).<ref name = SAC/>
===1889=== * Ascent by Achille Ratti (later [[Pope Pius XI]])<ref>[http://www.weltderberge.de/alpen/matter.htm Chronology of climbs] weltderberge.de. Retrieved 2010-02-03</ref>
===1895=== * August 25: [[Luigi Amedeo]], Duke of the Abruzzi, A. F. Mummery and [[J. Norman Collie]] made the ascent with the guide Josef Pollinger.<ref name = Rey/> * August 31: First descent of the Zmutt ridge by [[Matthias Zurbriggen]] and J. Pollinger guiding [[Lily Bristow]].<ref name=centenary/>
===1898=== * First solo ascent (Hörnli ridge) by {{Interlanguage link multi|Wilhelm Paulcke|de}}.<ref name = SAC/>
===1906=== * September 1: First solo ascent of the Zmutt ridge by {{Interlanguage link multi|Hans Pfann (explorer)|fr|Hans Pfann|lt=Hans Pfann}}.<ref name = SAC/>
===1911=== * September 9: First ascent via the Furggen ridge by [[Mario Piacenza]] with guides Jean-Joseph Carrel and Joseph Gaspard.<ref name = SAC/> * January 31: First winter ascent via the Hörnli ridge by [[Charles Francis Meade]] with the guides Josef Lochmatter and J. Pollinger.<ref name = SAC/>
===1923=== * August 12: Attempt on the north face by {{Interlanguage link multi|Alfred Horeschowsky|de}} and Franz Piekielko. The summit was reached via the Hörnli ridge.<ref name = SAC/>
===1928=== * August: Attempt on the north face by Kaspar Mooser and Victor Imboden.<ref name = SAC2>''Alpinisme Cervin/Dent Blanche Weisshorn, du Col Collon au Theodulpass'', 2012, [[Swiss Alpin Club]]</ref>
===1931=== * August 1: First ascent of the north face by the brothers {{Interlanguage link multi|Franz Schmid|fr|3=Franz Schmid|lt=Franz}} and {{Interlanguage link multi|Toni Schmid|fr}}.<ref name = SAC/> * October 15: First ascent of the south face by Enzo Benedetti with guides [[Luigi Carrel|Louis Carrel]] and Maurice Bich.<ref name = SAC/>
===1932=== * September 19: First complete ascent of the east face by Enzo Benedetti and Giuseppe Mazzotti with guides Louis and Lucien Carrel, M. Bich and Antoine Gaspard.<ref name = SAC/>
===1934=== * [[Paul Petzoldt]] traversed the Matterhorn and then retraced his route over the summit on the same day.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/09/us/paul-petzoldt-is-dead-at-91-innovator-in-rock-climbing.html?pagewanted=1 Paul Petzoldt Is Dead at 91; Innovator in Rock Climbing] nytimes.com, 9 October 1999</ref>
===1936=== * First winter solo ascent via the Hörnli ridge by [[Giusto Gervasutti]].<ref name = Collomb>Robin G. Collomb, ''Pennine Alps Central'', London: Alpine Club, 1975, pp. 241–59</ref>
===1948=== * March 25: First winter ascent via the Zmutt ridge by Henri Masson and Edmund Petrig.<ref name = Collomb/>
===1950=== * August 19: First ascent by a cat (Hörnli ridge). It climbed up entirely unaided, but made its descent in a guide's rucksack.<ref name=centenary/>
===1959=== * July 22: First solo ascent of the north face by Dieter Marchart.<ref name = SAC/> * Sept 1: First British, all-female, un-guided ascent (Hörnli ridge) by British students [[Freda Bean]] (nee Wilkinson) and Janette Curtis.
===1961=== <!--Called a post-war record. If someone already went faster before the war it certainly is not worth listing.--> * Fast ascent by Ian Angell in 3 hours and 25 minutes.<ref>[http://www.lynnnews.co.uk/news/local/latest-local-news/bells-ring-out-for-king-of-mountains-1-507704 Bells ring out for king of mountains] lynnnews.co.uk, 28 March 2006</ref>
===1962=== * February 4: First winter ascent of the north face by Hilti von Allmen and {{Interlanguage link multi|Paul Etter|de}}.<ref name = SAC/> * August 13: First complete ascent of the west face by Renato Daguin and Giovanni Ottin.<ref name = SAC/> All faces and ridges have been completely ascended<ref>{{HDS|8780|Matterhorn}}</ref>
===1965=== * February 22: In winter and alone, [[Walter Bonatti]] climbs a direct new route on the north face, the "North Face Direct". Bonatti set off on February 18, accompanied by three friends in order to simulate an ordinary day of alpine skiing. He prepared himself in secret behind a boulder, then for the next four days struggled against solitude, cold and technical difficulties.<ref name = SAC/><ref name = Alpinist>Herve Barmasse and Luca Maspes, July 2006, "The Matterhorn", ''Alpinist'', 16</ref> * July 13: [[Yvette Vaucher]], climbing with her husband Michel Vaucher, becomes the first woman to climb the Matterhorn's north face.<ref>{{cite book|title=Women Climbing: 200 Years of Achievement|year=1990|publisher=[[The Mountaineers (club)|The Mountaineers]]|last=Birkett|first=Bill|last2=Peascod|first2=Bill}}</ref>
===1969=== * Ascent of the north face by [[Jean Troillet]] in 4 hours and 10 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sampiero|first1=Josh|title=Dani Arnold's speed ascent of the Matterhorn North Face beats Ueli Steck for a new world record.|url=http://www.redbull.com/uk/en/adventure/stories/1331721067560/dani-arnold-speed-ascent-matterhorn|website=www.redbull.com|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref>
===1970=== *August Attempted ascent of the Swiss side of the Matterhorn by Japanese climbers Michio Oikawa and Masayuki Kobayashi who disappeared. Remains found in Sept 2014 and identified in August 2015<ref>[http://mashable.com/2015/08/07/japanese-climbers-alps-identified/ remains of 2 climbers identified]</ref>
===1971=== * December 23: First winter ascent via the south face by [[Arturo Squinobal]] and [[Oreste Squinobal]].<ref name = SAC/>
===1975=== * February 28: First winter ascent via the east face by René Arnold, Guido Bumann and Candide Pralong.<ref name = SAC/>
===1977=== * February 16: First winter solo ascent of the Schmid route on the north face by [[Tsuneo Hasegawa]].<ref name = SAC/>
===1978=== * January 11: First winter ascent of the west face by Rolando Albertini, Marco Barmasse, Innocenzo Menabreaz, Leo Pession, A. Squinobal, O. Squinobal and Augusto Tamone. Death of Rolando Albertini.<ref name = SAC/>
===1990=== * Mountain guide [[Ulrich Inderbinen]] makes his 370th and last ascent of the Matterhorn, before his 90th birthday.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1464607/Ulrich-Inderbinen.html Ulrich Inderbinen] telegraph.co.uk. Retrieved 2010-01-27</ref>
===1992=== * August 20: [[Hans Kammerlander]] and {{Interlanguage link multi|Diego Wellig|de}} climb the Matterhorn four times in 23 hours and 26 minutes. The route they followed was: Zmutt ridge–summit–Hörnli ridge (descent)–Furggen ridge–summit–Lion ridge (descent)–Lion ridge–summit–Hörnli ridge (descent)–Hörnli ridge–summit–Hörnli Hut (descent).<ref>La Stampa 08-21-1992, p. 12</ref>
===1994=== * March 11: Second ascent of the North Face Direct (Bonatti route) by [[Catherine Destivelle]] (started on 8th).<ref name = Alpinist/><ref>[http://www.summitpost.org/fact-sheet/254187/the-finest-alpinists-in-the-world.html#chapter_13 The finest alpinists in the world] summitpost.org. Retrieved 2010-01-27]</ref>
===1995=== * August 17: [[Bruno Brunod]] sprints up and down the Lion ridge from [[Breuil-Cervinia|Breuil]], ascending and descending 2469 vertical meters in 3hrs and 14 minutes.<ref name=lionsprint>[http://www.climbing.com/news/kilian-jornet-shatters-matterhorn-speed-record/ Kilian Jornet Shatters Matterhorn Speed Record]</ref>
===2007=== * September 6: Mountain guides Simon Anthamatten and Michael Lerjen, both of Zermatt, ascended and descended the Hörnli ridge in a record retour (combined time of ascent and descent) of 2 hours and 33 minutes (ascent: 1 hour and 40 minutes, descent: 53 minutes).<ref>[http://www.alpinist.com/doc/web07f/newswire-matterhorn-hornli-ridge-record Record retour on the Matterhorn's Hörnli ridge], alpinist.com, 20 September 2007</ref>
===2009=== * January 13: [[Ueli Steck]] climbs the classic Schmid route on the north face in 1 hour and 56 minutes.<ref>[http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?keyid=36559 Ueli Steck interview after Matterhorn solo in less than 2 hours], planetmountain.com, 23 January 2009</ref> * June: Swiss mountain guide [[Jean Troillet]] climbs a 600 meters new route on the north face.<ref>[http://www.up-climbing.com/en/news/mountaineering/jean-troillet-climbs-a-new-route-on-matterhorn-north-face Jean Troillet climbs a 600 meters new route on Matterhorn north face] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090810055419/http://www.up-climbing.com/en/news/mountaineering/jean-troillet-climbs-a-new-route-on-matterhorn-north-face |date=2009-08-10 }} up-climbing.org. Retrieved 2010-01-19</ref>
===2011=== * August 23: [[Andreas Steindl]] runs 2915 vertical meters from Zollhaus, [[Zermatt]], up the Matterhorn over the Hörnli ridge in a record time of 2 hours and 57 minutes.<ref>[http://climbing.about.com/b/2011/10/04/swiss-guide-climbs-matterhorn-in-sub-3-hour-sprint.htm Swiss Guide Climbs Matterhorn in Sub-3 Hour Sprint]</ref>
===2013=== * August 21: [[Kilian Jornet]] sprints up and down the shortest ridge of the Matterhorn in 2 hours and 52 minute, breaking Brunod's Lion ridge run from Breuil by 22 minutes <ref name=lionsprint/>
===2015=== *April 22: [[Dani Arnold]] climbs the classic Schmid route on the North Face in a one-hour and 46 minutes, 10 minutes faster than Ueli Steck in 2009.<ref>[http://www.climbing.com/news/dani-arnold-breaks-matterhorn-speed-record-video-photos/ Dani Arnold Breaks Matterhorn Speed Record], Climbing, 30 April 2015</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} * Helmut Dumler and Willi P. Burkhardt, ''The High Mountains of the Alps'', London: Diadem, 1994

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Triangle (''The X-Files'')}} {{use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox television episode |season=[[The X-Files (season 6)|6]] |image = |caption= |episode=3 |title=Triangle |series=[[The X-Files]] |length=45 minutes<ref>{{cite web|title=The X-Files, Season 6|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/tv-season/the-x-files-season-6/id283986520|work=[[iTunes Store]]|publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref> |guests= * [[Mitch Pileggi]] as [[Walter Skinner]]/[[Nazi]] officer * [[William B. Davis]] as [[Cigarette Smoking Man]]/Nazi officer * [[Chris Owens (actor)|Chris Owens]] as [[Jeffrey Spender]]/Nazi officer * Madison Mason as Captain Yip Harburg * [[James Pickens Jr.]] as [[Alvin Kersh]]/Jamaican crewman * [[Tom Braidwood]] as [[Melvin Frohike]] * [[Dean Haglund]] as [[Richard Langly]] * [[Bruce Harwood]] as [[John Fitzgerald Byers]] * Arlene Pileggi as Skinner's assistant * Laura Hughes as Kersh's assistant/girl singer<ref name="plot">[[#Meisler|Meisler (2000)]], pp. 30–39.</ref> |writer=Chris Carter |director=[[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]] |production=6ABX03<ref name="DVD"/> |airdate=November 22, 1998 |prev=[[Drive (The X-Files)|Drive]] |next=[[Dreamland (The X-Files)|Dreamland]] | season_article = The X-Files (season 6) | episode_list = List of The X-Files episodes }} "'''Triangle'''" is the third episode of the [[The X-Files (season 6)|sixth season]] of the American [[science fiction on television|science fiction]] television series ''[[The X-Files]]''. It premiered on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] network on November 22, 1998. Written and directed by series creator [[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]], "Triangle" is a "Monster-of-the-Week" episode, a stand-alone plot which is unconnected to the [[Mythology of The X-Files|overarching mythology]] of ''The X-Files''. "Triangle" earned a [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen household rating]] of 10.8, being watched by 18.20 million viewers in its initial broadcast. The episode generally received positive reviews with many critics commenting on the episode's directing style.
The show centers on [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] special agents [[Fox Mulder]] ([[David Duchovny]]) and [[Dana Scully]] ([[Gillian Anderson]]) who work on cases linked to the paranormal, called [[X-File]]s. Mulder is a believer in the paranormal, the skeptical Scully has been assigned to debunk his work and the two have developed a close friendship. In this episode, Mulder races to a luxury passenger liner which has mysteriously appeared in the [[Bermuda Triangle]]. Once there, he realizes he has traveled back in time to September 3, 1939—the outbreak of [[World War II]]. German soldiers have boarded the ship in search of "Thor's Hammer", something that could ensure victory in the coming conflict. Scully, after being informed of Mulder's disappearance by [[The Lone Gunmen]], rushes through the [[J. Edgar Hoover Building]], looking for someone who can help find her missing partner.
"Triangle" is filmed in a style inspired by the 1948 [[Alfred Hitchcock]] film ''[[Rope (film)|Rope]]'', with many scenes edited to appear as single takes. In addition, "Triangle" features the main and recurring cast members such as Anderson, [[William B. Davis]], [[Chris Owens (actor)|Chris Owens]], [[James Pickens Jr.]] and [[Mitch Pileggi]], who played their contemporary characters as well as distinctly different characters from 1939 on board the luxury liner. Several of the episode's themes have been critically examined, such as the concept of "dream-nazis", the appearance of modern characters portraying those from the past, and the ramification that the entire episode was a dream.
==Plot== [[Fox Mulder]] ([[David Duchovny]]) lies unconscious in the sea after wrecking his raft. He is taken aboard a passenger ship, the ''Queen Anne'', by its British crew members. When he is sent to meet the captain, Mulder tries to explain that the ''Queen Anne'' vanished in the [[Bermuda Triangle]] in 1939, and claims that it has reappeared in 1998. The crew dismisses Mulder's story and suspect he is a [[Nazi]] spy. At that moment, the ''Queen Anne'' is boarded by [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] troops under the control of an ''[[Oberführer]]'' resembling [[The Smoking Man]] ([[William B. Davis]]), who sets the ship's course for [[Nazi Germany]]. The crew of the ''Queen Anne'' lock Mulder in the captain's quarters, where he listens to a radio broadcast announcing the start of [[World War II]]. Mulder realizes that the ''Queen Anne'' did not travel to 1998: he has traveled back to 1939.
In the present, [[The Lone Gunmen]] inform [[Dana Scully]] ([[Gillian Anderson]]) that they have lost contact with Mulder, who had set out in search of the ''Queen Anne''. Scully first turns to [[Walter Skinner]] ([[Mitch Pileggi]]), unsuccessfully, then attempts to confront [[FBI#Organization and rank structure|Assistant Director]] [[Alvin Kersh]] ([[James Pickens Jr.]]) who is seen with the Smoking Man. She finally threatens Agent [[Jeffrey Spender]] ([[Chris Owens (actor)|Chris Owens]]) before Skinner shows up and provides her with the information from the [[United States Department of Defense|Pentagon]]. Scully leaves with the Gunmen to find Mulder. On the ''Queen Anne'', a British sailor tells Mulder that the Germans are looking for what they believe is a weapon called "Thor's Hammer". Mulder tells him that Thor's Hammer is not a weapon, but a scientist that will build [[Nuclear weapon|a weapon]]. The sailor turns out to be a German spy and locks Mulder in the engine room with the ship's crew. One of the sailors, who strongly resembles Kersh, decides to steer the boat to Jamaica, but Mulder tells them to sail back where they came from, in order to pass through the time warp and re-appear in 1998.
Eventually, Mulder is taken to the ballroom by the Nazis. Once there, he is ordered to identify the scientist, or the Nazis will begin shooting passengers. After they have killed two men, a woman who looks strikingly like Scully tells the Nazis that they are killing innocent people for nothing, and that Mulder knows nothing. Mulder tells the Nazis that one of the men they shot was the scientist, but the true scientist steps forward. The Nazis prepare to execute Mulder and "Scully", but before they are able, the engine is shut down. British sailors descend upon the ballroom and begin fighting the Nazis. In the midst of the chaos, Mulder and "Scully" escape. Scully and the Lone Gunmen find the ''Queen Anne'' and board it, only to find that it is an empty ghost ship.
Back in 1939, as the British sailors fight the Nazis in the ballroom, Mulder tells "Scully" that she has to turn the ship around and return to the Bermuda Triangle in order to get the ship out of the rift in space. Mulder grabs "Scully" and kisses her, "in case we never meet again". "Scully" punches him, and he jumps overboard. Mulder wakes up in 1998 in a hospital, surrounded by Scully, the Lone Gunmen and Skinner. Mulder attempts to tell them that he traveled to 1939, and of his encounter with Nazis, and tells Scully that she was there with him, but they all think he is delirious. After Skinner and the Gunmen leave, Mulder calls Scully back and tells her that he loves her. Scully thinks his declaration is an effect of the drugs he has been given, rolls her eyes and leaves. As he lies down, Mulder winces as his cheek touches the pillow; the spot where "Scully" punched him in 1939 is still sore and visibly bruised. Mulder feels his eye-socket and breaks into a knowing smile.<ref name="plot"/>
==Production==
===Conception, writing, and filming=== [[File:RMS Queen Mary Long Beach January 2011 view.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The scenes aboard the ''Queen Anne'' were actually filmed on board the RMS ''Queen Mary''.|alt=The picture is of a large luxury liner.]]
''The X-Files'' creator Chris Carter developed the idea for "Triangle" while working on the [[The X-Files (season 5)|fifth-season]] episode "[[The Red and the Black (The X-Files)|The Red and the Black]]".<ref name="m39">[[#Meisler|Meisler (2000)]], p. 39.</ref> While filming the episode, Carter used so much film that the crew made him a mock trophy. This, in turn, inspired him to write an episode that featured continuous action, thereby using as little film as possible.<ref name="m40"/> Carter designed "Triangle" in a style similar to [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s 1948 film ''[[Rope (film)|Rope]]''.<ref name="sun">{{cite news|last=Strachan|first=Alex|title=X-Files Producer Can't Let Go of Vancouver|url=http://www.turning-pages.com/carterconnection/112198sun.htm|accessdate=December 26, 2011|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.|date=November 21, 1998}}</ref> Initially, [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] executives were hesitant to [[green-light]] production for "Triangle" because it was expected to exceed the $2.5 million episode budget. To persuade them, Carter told the executives that the episode would feature elements of Hitchcock's directing style, a move he later called "an easy hook".<ref name="EW"/> Carter also cited the 1964 ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|Twilight Zone]]'' adaptation of "[[An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge (film)|An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge]]" as inspiration.<ref name="EW"/>
The scenes taking place on the ''Queen Anne'' were filmed aboard the retired British [[ocean liner]] [[RMS Queen Mary|RMS ''Queen Mary'']], which is moored at [[Long Beach, California]] and currently serves as a hotel.<ref name="sun"/><ref name="EW"/><ref name="interview">{{cite interview |last=Anderson |first=Gillian |subjectlink=Gillian Anderson|title=Electronic Press Kit for "Triangle"<!-- |url=http://shippers.fredfarm.com/multimedia/index1.htm INCLUDED JUST FOR VERIFICATION, EVEN THOUGH WE CAN'T LINK TO IT SINCE IT'S A COPY VIO -->|year=1998|publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Company]]}}</ref> Filming on board the ship took place over eleven days. To block out the lights of nearby Long Beach, ''The X-Files'' crew erected wrap-around scaffolding on the ship's bridge.<ref name="m40"/> To give the effect of rain during the scenes on the bridge, the crew installed large sprinkler systems that provided a constant supply of water.<ref name="epcom"/> Unhappy with the remodeled style of the ship's corridors and ballroom, Carter had whole portions of the ship redesigned so that the finished episode would have a late-1930s feel.<ref name="m40"/><ref name="m41"/>
For authenticity, several British and German actors portrayed the British sailors and Nazi soldiers, whose dialogue was mostly in German. Trevor Goddard, who portrayed the First British Crewman, is English, while Madison Mason, who played Captain Yip Harburg, is American; he affected an English accent for the part.<ref name="Triangle">{{cite AV media|people=[[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Carter, Chris]]|date=1999|title=The Truth About Season Six|medium=DVD|publisher=[[20th Century Fox Home Entertainment]]}}</ref> William B. Davis' dialogue was entirely in German, a language which he did not speak. He later explained, "I certainly didn't realize I was going to be speaking a lot of German until I got the script, which just said 'CSM (in German)'."<ref name=CSMinterview/> To successfully learn his lines, one of the German cast members recorded all of Davis' dialogue onto a [[Compact Cassette|cassette]]. Davis was given the cassette two weeks before shooting and phonetically memorized his lines; he noted that the method "seemed to work pretty well—at least to non-German-speaking people! It was a little more challenging because there were some real German speakers on the show, which I thought was a little unfair."<ref name=CSMinterview>{{cite journal|last=Hughes|first=Davis|title=William B. Davis: TV's Best Bad Guy, Cigarette-Smoking Man, Still Smolders as he Reveals New Dimensions|journal=[[Cinefantastique]]|date=October 1999|volume=31|issue=8|pages=32–35}}</ref> [[Tom Braidwood]], who played Lone Gunman Melvin Frohike and was an assistant director on the show, called Davis' role "brutal" and noted that "It was really tough for William because he had to learn all this German."<ref name="bigbook"/> Davis later joked that "Maybe we shouldn't try to do two clever things at once. I think it worked fine, but it was a struggle to do it."<ref name="bigbook"/> The only main cast member of ''The X-Files'' who already spoke German was Mitch Pileggi.<ref name="m41"/> Pileggi had studied in Germany; he had to re-write many of his lines as they made no sense in the context of the scenes.<ref name="bigbook">[[#Hurwitz|Hurwitz and Knowles (2008)]], p. 158.</ref> The tagline that usually appears after the opening credits of every episode, "The Truth is Out There", was translated into German: "Die Wahrheit ist irgendwo da draußen".<ref name="m41"/>
===Directing style=== [[File:ScullyFBITriangle.ogv|thumb|275px|right|alt=Video clip of a scene in the episode featuring Agent Scully crossing paths with Mulder and the 1939 version of Scully.|Agent Scully crosses paths with Agent Mulder and the 1939 version of Scully. The sophisticated split-screen [[mise en scène]] was inspired by the music video for [[Semisonic]]'s 1998 single "[[Closing Time (Semisonic song)|Closing Time]]."]] Filmed in [[Real time (media)|real time]], the episode is designed to look like it was recorded in four uninterrupted eleven-minute [[Shot (filmmaking)|takes]].<ref name="Triangle"/> Carter explained, "I said [to the cast and crew] 'Wouldn't it be great since we have 44 minutes of programming time if we just did an episode where we did four 11-minute takes and put it all together?' And everyone looked at me like I was nuts."<ref name="bigbook2">[[#Hurwitz|Hurwitz and Knowles (2008)]], p. 157.</ref> To film the episode, camera operator Dave Luckenbach wore a [[steadicam]]. The steadicam used could only hold a maximum of four minutes of film, so discreet edits and cuts were necessary.<ref name="EW"/> Luckenbach later likened the physical aftermath of filming to playing football, "You'd have a game on Friday, and you'd wake up Saturday and really feel it."<ref name="EW"/> The cuts were usually made during [[whip pan]]s or in scenes when the screen would go dark.<ref name="EW"/><ref name="Triangle"/> With the exception of Mulder jumping off the ''Queen Anne'', the only noticeable editing occurs between scenes, when a side swipe shifts between the two different time periods.<ref name="Triangle"/> Many of the takes needed to be nearly perfect; for example, of the takes made on the eighth day of filming, only two of ten were deemed satisfactory.<ref name="EW"/> Both the cast and crew admitted that filming an episode of ''The X-Files'' in real time was physically and mentally exhausting. Duchovny later joked that, after filming concluded, he "could win an Emmy for most bruises."<ref name="EW"/> Gillian Anderson described the real time directing style as "challenging."<ref name="interview"/> She said, "I'm realizing how comfortable and connected I am to the rhythm we're used to."<ref name="interview"/>
In an interview before the episode was finished, Gillian Anderson said she was most looking forward to the scene in which Scully takes an elevator through FBI headquarters in her quest to locate Mulder.<ref name="interview"/> She later compared the episode to live theater,<ref name="m41"/> which she had worked in previously.<ref>[[#Lowry|Lowry (1995)]], pp. 15–16.</ref> During the filming of this scene, when the actors entered the stage elevator, the set that they would next move onto had to be constructed behind the closed doors. Many times during filming, these doors would open before the set behind had been completed, which ruined the shot.<ref name="m40">[[#Meisler|Meisler (2000)]], p. 40.</ref> The final two acts of the episode feature a sophisticated split-screen [[mise en scène]]: Rather than displaying two different events, each side of the screen features the same setting, but with each side set during a different time period. When Scully runs around the corner in the present day, she does so at the same time as Mulder and the 1939 version of Scully. This was filmed in such a way that as the actors pass each other in the hallway, they also pass into the opposite frame of the split screen.<ref name="Triangle"/> This effect was inspired by the music video for [[Semisonic]]'s hit 1998 single "[[Closing Time (Semisonic song)|Closing Time]]."<ref name="EW">{{cite journal|last=Russo|first=Tom|title=Past Perfect|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,285813,00.html|accessdate=December 28, 2011|volume=459|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|date=November 20, 1998}}</ref>
Editor Louise Innes, who was working on her first ''X-Files'' episode, said the post-production editing process was "not as easy as it sounds."<ref name="EW"/> Innes was tasked with connecting roughly forty shots and creating the illusion of one, uniform scene.<ref name="EW"/> After the reels of film were combined, several pending issues had to be tweaked in post-production. For instance, during the scene in which Scully runs into an elevator, two shots were spliced together, but the color did not completely match. The images and their colors were later corrected by the series' "postproduction {{sic}} troubleshooters" using digital manipulation.<ref name="EW"/> When the episode was filmed, it was shot in 2.35:1 widescreen. When the episode aired, it was shown [[letterbox]]ed to fit in a 1.33:1 television screen; this was the first ''X-Files'' episode to receive this treatment. Carter reasoned that this method would allow for more action to be viewable in each frame.<ref name="m41"/>
===Music and cultural references=== To get a feel for the era, ''X-Files'' composer [[Mark Snow]] listened to the [[big band]] music of [[Tommy Dorsey]], [[Harry James]], [[Gene Krupa]], and [[Glenn Miller]]. The "bouncy instrumental" that plays during the ballroom fight scene was inspired by a similar [[swing (music)|swing]] tune, written by [[John Williams (composer)|John Williams]], from the 1979 [[Steven Spielberg]] film ''[[1941 (film)|1941]]''. Snow later joked that his composition was "the third generation of the same inspiration."<ref name="m41"/> Carter had significant musical input when it came to scene transitions, saying, "I got a chance to use some of my favorite '40s music here, too, or '30s and '40s music to transition scenes."<ref name="Triangle"/> Producer [[Paul Rabwin]] also supervised "a special arrangement" of the 1938 jazz standard "[[Jeepers Creepers (song)|Jeepers Creepers]]", which was also included in the ballroom scene.<ref name="m41"/>
The episode contains many intentional references to the 1939 musical film ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]''.<ref name="sun"/> The ship's captain is named after the film's lyricist [[Yip Harburg]], and the ballroom singer, Almira Gulch, after ''The Wizard of Oz'' character who is the analog for the [[Wicked Witch of the West]]. Her band is The Lollipop Guild, a reference to a section of the song "[[Ding-Dong! The Witch Is Dead]]", while Mulder's wrecked ship is called the ''Lady Garland'', after [[Judy Garland]].<ref name="m41"/> The final scene of "Triangle", which features Mulder in bed telling his friends and co-workers that he saw them in his reverie, bears a striking resemblance to the closing scene of ''Oz''. Because of this, the scene was called "obviously derivative" by one reviewer.<ref name="song parody"/> Further, when Mulder mentions that Skinner was with him in 1939, which is the year ''The Wizard of Oz'' was released, Skinner replies "with my dog [[Toto (Oz)|Toto]]", and Scully tells him "there's no place like home".<ref name="epcom"/><ref name="m41">[[#Meisler|Meisler (2000)]], p. 41.</ref><ref name="triangleep">{{Cite episode|title=Triangle|credits=[[Chris Carter (screenwriter)|Chris Carter]] (Writer and Director)|series=The X-Files|serieslink=The X-Files|network=Fox|airdate=November 22, 1998|season=6|number=3}}</ref>
The episode features several historical errors. Anderson's 1939 character is said to work for the [[Office of Strategic Services]], which was not established until 1942. The code name "Thor's Hammer" is an invention of the writers. Lee Smith, the official researcher for the show, was tasked with finding the name for the secret pre-World War II atomic research project. Unfortunately for the show, the actual code name, [[Manhattan Project|Development of Substitute Materials]], was considered "uninspiring," so the name "Thor's Hammer" was created instead.<ref name="m41"/>
==Themes== [[Robert Shearman]] and [[Lars Pearson]], in their book ''Wanting to Believe: A Critical Guide to The X-Files, Millennium & The Lone Gunmen'', examined the characterization of the villains in the episode and the [[meta-reference]]s to the series. Shearman and Pearson note that the episode makes a distinct difference when portraying the Nazis on-screen. Instead of showing them as "real Nazis"—like those featured in the third-season episode "[[Paper Clip]]", among others—this episode portrays them as deliberately exaggerated "dream-nazis".<ref name="shearman"/> The two argue that the villains are played as "comic book nasties" and are similar in style to the villains from the ''[[Indiana Jones (franchise)|Indiana Jones]]'' movie franchise.<ref name="shearman">[[#Shearman|Shearman and Pearson (2009)]], pp. 169–70.</ref>
Shearman and Pearson analyzed the portrayals of several of the series' regular characters as 1930s villains, noting several meta-references to the wider series. The two noted that, in his portrayal of a Nazi, Jeffrey Spender was allowed to "cut loose and rant like a proper villain rather than a sulky boy hiding in the basement."<ref name="shearman"/> In contrast, Walter Skinner's 1939 character behaved more like his character in the wider series, his role "charmingly parodying the ambiguity he's been playing all these years and turning out to be an American-loving ally who tells our heroes to get their 'asses out of here'."<ref name="shearman"/>
Tom Kessenich, in his book ''Examinations: An Unauthorized Look at Season 6–9 of The X-Files'', critically examined the ideas that the entire episode was either a dream or existed in some sort of "parallel universe".<ref name="examinations2"/><ref name="examinations3"/> Kessenich reasons that, because the episode contains several overt references to ''The Wizard of Oz'' and the fact that Chris Carter noted that the episode was based on the idea of Mulder's subconscious mind at work, much of "Triangle" was simply a dream.<ref name="examinations2">[[#Examinations|Kessenich (2002)]], p. 18.</ref> Furthermore, Kessenich backs up his argument by pointing out that many of the characters on the ship were played by familiar faces—The Smoking Man as the Nazi leader, Spender as a Nazi "lap dog", Skinner as a double agent, Kersh as an "unfamiliar friend or foe", and Scully as Mulder's ultimate ally.<ref name="examinations3">[[#Examinations|Kessenich (2002)]], p. 19.</ref> This would suggest, according to Kessenich, that the entire episode was acted out in Mulder's mind while he was unconscious in the Bermuda Triangle.<ref name="examinations3"/>
==Reception==
===Ratings=== Promoted with the tagline "Tonight, they get carried away... On a doomed voyage, the passion between Mulder and Scully is finally unstoppable",<ref>{{Cite sign|title=Triangle|year=1998|type=Promotional Flyer|publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Company]]|location=Los Angeles|url=http://i550.photobucket.com/albums/ii421/maurisap/xfiles%20forum/91getcarriedaway.jpg}}</ref> "Triangle" premiered on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] network in the United States on November 22, 1998.<ref name="DVD">{{cite AV media notes|title=The X-Files: The Complete Sixth Season|titlelink=The X-Files (season 6)|origyear=1998–1999|others=[[Kim Manners]], et al|type=booklet|publisher=[[Fox Broadcasting Corporation|Fox]]}}</ref> The episode earned a [[Nielsen rating]] of 10.8, with a 16 share, meaning that roughly 10.8 percent of all television-equipped households and 16 percent of households watching television were tuned in. It was viewed by 18.2 million viewers.<ref name="rating">[[#Meisler|Meisler (2000)]], p. 294.</ref> "Triangle" was the 18th most watched television program for the week ending November 22.<ref>{{cite news|title=Here Are the Prime-Time Ratings as Compiles|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/s/InfoWeb/aggdocs/NewsBank/0EB5E35CD823DB20/0F8479522BD09CA1?s_lang=en-US|accessdate=March 20, 2012|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|publisher=[[MediaNews Group]]|date=November 26, 1998}} {{subscription needed}}</ref> The episode aired in the United Kingdom and Ireland on [[Sky1]] on March 21, 1999, and received 0.74 million viewers, making it the fourth most watched program that week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barb.co.uk/viewing/weekly-top-10/?|title=BARB's multichannel top 10 programmes|publisher=barb.co.uk|accessdate=January 1, 2012}} Note: Information is in the section titled "w/e March 15–21, 1999", listed under Sky1</ref>
===Initial reception=== When the finished program was shown to the cast and crew, their response was very positive. Gillian Anderson said, "I never quite understood whether it was going to work or not. When we finally saw 'Triangle' after this new way of filming everything, a style that we'd never attempted before, as well as trying new scenes ... trying this, trying that ...  that was terrific."<ref name="bigbook"/> Chris Owens, who portrayed the Agent Spender Nazi lookalike, said, "One thing I really like about ''The X-Files'' was that they were always challenging themselves. Chris [Carter] would write an episode in which we're going to do ''Rope'' without any cuts, seemingly. A great challenge for a cast and crew."<ref name="bigbook"/><ref name="bigbook2"/>
The episode received generally positive critical reviews from the press. Matt Zoller Seitz from ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'' gave an overwhelmingly positive review of "Triangle". Applauding Carter's risky and audacious direction, he noted that "there has never been an hour of TV that looks or moves like 'Triangle'".<ref name=starled/> He argued that the 1939 scene where Mulder and "Scully" cross paths with present-Scully was "the greatest minute of TV this year".<ref name=starled/> Seitz also compared the episode to three-dimensional video games, like ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'', ''[[Quake (video game)|Quake]]'', and ''[[Castle Wolfenstein]]'', citing the episode's "gloomy corridors" and "nightmarish cartoon Nazis".<ref name=starled>{{cite news|last=Seitz|first=Matt Zoller|title=Just Watch It – 'X-Files' Episode Sails Into Bermuda Triangle, But Instead of Sinking, Soars with Brilliance|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/s/InfoWeb/aggdocs/NewsBank/0EFDA6209EDC5D07/0F8479522BD09CA1?s_lang=en-US|accessdate=March 20, 2012|work=[[The Star-Ledger]]|publisher=[[Advance Publications]]|date=November 22, 1998}} {{subscription needed}}</ref> Michael Liedtke and George Avalos from ''[[The Charlotte Observer]]'' predicted that "'Triangle' seems destined to take its rightful place in the pantheon of greatest 'X-Files' episodes".<ref name="song parody"/> Enjoying the plethora of ''Wizard of Oz'' references, the two parodied a portion of "[[Over the Rainbow]]" in their column.<ref name="song parody">{{cite news|last=Liedtke|first=Michael|title=Ace 'X-Files' Episode Takes Mulder Beyond Kansas, Toto|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/s/InfoWeb/aggdocs/NewsBank/0EB6D637923316A4/0F8479522BD09CA1?s_lang=en-US|accessdate=March 20, 2012|work=[[Charlotte Observer]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|date=December 2, 1998|author2=George Avalos|agency=[[Knight Ridder]]}} {{subscription needed}}</ref>{{refn|The parody included the lines: "Somewhere beneath the conspiracy, romantic hopes soar / Mulder and Scully often hug beneath the conspiracy, why, oh why, can't they do more?"<ref name="song parody"/>|group="nb"}} Not all reviewers were so positive; for [[Alan Sepinwall]], "Triangle" was the episode "that turned out to be a dream", making it "technically impressive but dramatically murky".<ref name=starled2>{{cite news|last=Sepinwall|first=Alan|title=All TV – 'X-Files' Creator Breaks His Vows|work=[[The Star-Ledger]]|publisher=[[Advance Publications]]|date=December 11, 1998}}</ref>
===Later reception=== Several years after its initial broadcast, "Triangle" has continued to receive positive reviews, with many critics calling it one of the show's best episodes. Jessica Morgan from [[Television Without Pity]] gave the episode an A–.<ref>{{cite web|title=X-Files TV Show — Triangle — X-Files Recaps, X-Files Reviews, X-Files Episodes |author=Morgan, Jessica |url=http://www.televisionwithoutpity.com/show/the-xfiles/triangle-1.php |work=[[Television Without Pity]] |publisher=[[NBCUniversal]] |accessdate=December 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.li/20120913114940/http://www.televisionwithoutpity.com/show/the-xfiles/triangle-1.php |archivedate=September 13, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Earl Cressey from ''[[DVD Talk]]'' called it one of the highlights of season six.<ref name=dvdtalk>{{cite web|last=Cressey|first=Earl|title=X-Files: Season Six|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/4819/x-files-season-six/|work=[[DVD Talk]]|publisher=[[Internet Brands|Internet Brands Inc]]|accessdate=March 14, 2012|date=November 5, 2002}}</ref> Shearman and Pearson rated the episode five stars out of five and called it a "shining gem of an episode."<ref name="shearman"/>
Carter's helmsmanship of "Triangle" received mostly favorable critical attention. Shearman and Pearson praised his directing, pointing to the scene where Scully dashes through the FBI building as "the best scene of all".<ref name="shearman"/> Todd VanDerWerff of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', in an "A" grade review, appreciated the style of filming, and wrote that the long scenes give "the whole thing a sense of urgency that propels scenes that shouldn't work".<ref name=avclub/> In addition, he called the split-screen shot "darn near perfect"; VanDerWerff later labeled it "one of my favorite moments in the whole show".<ref name=avclub/> Andrew Payne from ''Starpulse'' applauded the acting and directing, saying, "Chris Carter rarely directed his creation, leaving that mostly to Kim Manners, but when he did he showed a brilliant eye not usually seen on broadcast TV. This is the best example—a breathlessly-paced episode in which each act appears as one continuous shot. ... This episode is a lot of fun, particularly in the act that finds Scully blitzing through the FBI building in order to get some information on Mulder's whereabouts. The acting is superb and nothing can beat those no-cut acts."<ref>{{cite web|last=Payne|first=Andrew|title='X-Files' 10 Best Episodes|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Andrew_Payne/2008/07/25/x_files_10_best_episodes|work=Starpulse|publisher=Media Holdings LLC|date=July 25, 2008|accessdate=November 16, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111219002540/http://www.starpulse.com/news/Andrew_Payne/2008/07/25/x_files_10_best_episodes|archivedate=December 19, 2011|df=}}</ref> Payne ultimately named it the fourth best ''X-Files'' episode. David Boston from ''Made Man'' wrote that "we know whenever [Chris Carter] directs an episode it is always among the best."<ref>{{cite web|last=Boston|first=David|title=5 Best 'X Files' Episodes|url=http://www.mademan.com/mm/5-best-x-files-episodes.html|work=Made Man|publisher=[[Break Media]]|date=December 11, 2010|accessdate=March 20, 2012}}</ref> Timothy Sexton from [[Yahoo! Voices]] praised the split-screen scene and the scene featuring Scully running through the FBI building, comparing it favorably to [[Orson Welles]]' 1958 film ''[[Touch of Evil]]''.<ref name=yahoo>{{cite web|last=Sexton |first=Timothy |title=Top Ten X-Files Episodes |url=http://voices.yahoo.com/top-ten-x-files-episodes-47410.html?cat=40 |work=[[Yahoo! Voices]] |publisher=[[Yahoo!|Yahoo! Inc]] |accessdate=March 20, 2012 |date=June 26, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.li/20130209212124/http://voices.yahoo.com/top-ten-x-files-episodes-47410.html?cat=40 |archivedate=February 9, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Jonathan Dunn, writing for What Culture, described "Triangle" as "great" and included it in the "5 Episodes [of ''The X-Files''] That Could Be Made Into Movies" list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whatculture.com/tv/the-x-files-5-episodes-that-could-be-made-into-movies.php/2|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502022534/http://whatculture.com/tv/the-x-files-5-episodes-that-could-be-made-into-movies.php/2|title=The X-Files: 5 Episodes That Could Be Made Into Movies|work=What Culture|author=Dunn, Jonathan|date=April 29, 2013|archivedate=May 2, 2013}}</ref> In the 1999 [[FX (TV channel)|FX]] [[Thanksgiving]] Marathon, containing fan-selected episodes, "Triangle" was presented as the "Best Chris Carter-Directed Episode".<ref>{{cite AV media|title=The X-Files Thanksgiving Marathon (November 25, 1999)|medium=TV|publisher=[[TV channel|FX]]}}</ref> Not all reviews were as glowing; Paula Vitaris from ''[[Cinefantastique]]'' wrote that "everyone certainly deserves an A for effort", she was unimpressed by the "vertiginous camerawork" and "endless, monotonous tracking shots up and down hallways".<ref name=cinepaula/> She ultimately awarded it one-and-a-half stars out of four.<ref name=cinepaula>{{cite journal|last=Vitaris|first=Paula|title=Sixth Season Episode Guide|journal=[[Cinefantastique]]|date=October 1999|volume=31|issue=8|pages=26–42}}</ref>
In addition, many reviewers were pleased with the style and concept of "Triangle". Tom Kessenich lauded the atmosphere of the entry, calling it "60 minutes of ''The X-Files'' at its finest".<ref name="examinations"/> Kessenich noted that, despite the "gloom and doom" talk that the series was heading in the wrong direction, stylistically, the episode proved "just how exciting this show can be".<ref name="examinations">[[#Examinations|Kessenich (2002)]], p. 17.</ref> He ultimately concluded that it was "a wonderful blend of fantasy and reality" that allowed the viewer "to try and ascertain what is real and what is not."<ref name="kesstop"/> He later named "Triangle" one of the "Top 25 Episode of All Time" of ''The X-Files'', and ranked it in second place.<ref name="kesstop">[[#Examinations|Kessenich (2002)]], p. 219.</ref> VanDerWerff noted that he thoroughly enjoyed the concept, pointing out that the "sheer level of crazy stuff that goes on in this episode makes it fun to watch".<ref name=avclub/> He wrote that "[n]othing else had ever been this skillfully done on television before", which resulted in a "terrific episode of television".<ref name=avclub/> Furthermore, he opined that "[e]verything comes together in the episode's fantastically entertaining final act", due to the presence of the dramatic fight scene, among others.<ref name=avclub>{{cite web|last=VanDerWerff|first=Todd|title='Triangle'/'TEOTWAWKI' {{!}} TV Club {{!}} TV |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/triangleteotwawki,81163/|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=[[The Onion]]|accessdate=June 17, 2012|date=June 16, 2012}}</ref>
"Triangle" features the first kiss between Mulder and Scully.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fall|first=Kerry|title=The X-Files: Season Six|url=http://www.dvdjournal.com/quickreviews/x/xfiles.season6.q.shtml|publisher=DVD Journal|accessdate=January 11, 2012}}</ref> Kessenich opined that the kiss built off "the seeds that were planted in [[The X-Files (film)|the movie]] ... Scully clearly believes this is a man lost in delirium, but Mulder ... is finally beginning to deal with some pretty powerful feelings he has for his partner."<ref name="examinations"/> Paula Vitaris, on the other hand, was frustrated; she complained "[w]hen are these kisses that are not kisses going to end?"<ref name=cinepaula/>
===Awards=== The episode received a [[51st Primetime Emmy Awards|1999]] [[Emmy Award]] nomination for Outstanding Sound Editing for a Series.<ref name="epcom">{{cite AV media|people=Chris Carter (Writer, Director)|date=November 5, 2002|title=Triangle: Episode Commentary|location=''[[The X-Files (season 6)|The X-Files: The Complete Sixth Season]]''|medium=DVD|publisher=20th Century Fox Home Entertainment}}</ref>{{refn|Jeff Charbonneau (Music Editor); Thierry J. Couturier (Supervising Sound Editor); Stuart Calderon, Michael Goodman, Jay Levine, [[Maciek Malish]] M.P.S.E., George Nemzer, Cecilia Perna, Chris Reeves, and Gabrielle Reeves (Sound Editors); and Gary Marullo and Mike Salvetta (Foley Artists) were nominated for the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/award_history_search?person=&program=the+x-files&start_year=1999&end_year=1999&network=All&web_category=All&winner=All|title=Primetime Emmy® Award Database — The X-Files|work=Emmys.com|publisher=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]]|accessdate=January 26, 2012}}</ref>|group="nb"}}
